headline: L’Oréal to acquire Kering’s beauty unit for €4 billion
title: L’Oréal to acquire Kering’s beauty unit for €4 billion
summary: L’Oréal is acquiring the beauty division of Kering, including luxury fragrance brand Creed and long-term licences for Gucci, Balenciaga, and Bottega Veneta — a strategic move that strengthens its premium portfolio.
full_text: Sale includes Creed and long-term fragrance licences for Bottega Veneta and Balenciaga. The deal marks the first major move by new Kering CEO Luca de Meo and L’Oreal’s largest acquisition to date, surpassing 2023’s 2.5 billion dollar Aesop purchase. Kering has agreed to sell its beauty business to L’Oreal for 4 billion euros (4.7 billion dollars), as de Meo aims to cut the group’s debt and refocus operations. L’Oreal will acquire Kering’s fragrance brand Creed and obtain exclusive 50-year licences to develop beauty products for Kering’s fashion labels including Bottega Veneta and Balenciaga. The sale reverses former CEO François-Henri Pinault’s strategy, who had acquired Creed in 2023 for 3.5 billion euros. Analysts called the transaction a pragmatic step, allowing Kering to reduce its 9.5 billion euro net debt, while L’Oreal strengthens its position in luxury fragrances. Kering’s shares rose 4.8 percent and L’Oreal’s 1.2 percent after the announcement. The agreement also grants L’Oreal a 50-year Gucci licence once Kering’s existing deal with Coty expires, expected around 2028. De Meo signalled that more divestments could follow, focusing Kering on businesses where it has scale and expertise. Kering’s beauty division, created in 2023, had posted a 60 million euro operating loss in the first half of the year amid weaker Gucci sales, especially in China. The sale helps alleviate pressure from slowing growth and high leverage. Kering has already delayed a full takeover of Valentino and plans to monetise parts of its real estate portfolio. For L’Oreal, the acquisition broadens its luxury portfolio alongside Yves Saint Laurent, whose rights it bought from Kering in 2008. Experts described the 4 billion euro price as justified, giving L’Oreal access to prestigious but underdeveloped brands and limited competition for the asset. Kering was advised by Evercore and Centerview, while L’Oreal worked with Bank of America and Rothschild. The transaction is expected to close in the first half of 2026.

headline: Sales at 30 September 2025: group sales €32.8 bn
title: Sales at 30 September 2025: group sales €32.8 bn
summary: L’Oréal reported nine-month sales of €32.8 bn with like-for-like growth of 3.4%, supported by a rebound in the US and China markets that lifted investor sentiment.
full_text: L’Oréal reported sales of 32.8 billion euros for the first nine months of 2025, up 3.4 percent like-for-like and 1.2 percent on a reported basis. Growth accelerated across all divisions and regions, supported by strong momentum in haircare and fragrances, an improving makeup segment, and double-digit online growth. The recovery in North America and mainland China continued, while Europe remained robust. CEO Nicolas Hieronimus said third-quarter growth reached 4.9 percent like-for-like, driven by broad-based progress and strong contributions from new product launches. He highlighted the newly announced strategic partnership with Kering, including the acquisition of Creed and long-term beauty licences for Gucci, Bottega Veneta and Balenciaga, which will strengthen L’Oréal’s luxury beauty leadership. By division, Professional Products grew 7.4 percent like-for-like, Consumer Products 3.1 percent, Luxe 2.2 percent, and Dermatological Beauty 3.7 percent. Growth was driven by innovation and expanding e-commerce channels. Notable launches included Kérastase Gloss Absolu, Maybelline Colossal Bubble Mascara, and Prada Paradigme. By region, Europe rose 3.6 percent, North America 1.8 percent, North Asia 0.5 percent, SAPMENA–SSA 11.0 percent, and Latin America 8.2 percent like-for-like. China returned to growth, Japan and Korea performed strongly, and emerging markets like India, Vietnam, and Brazil led momentum. Recent events include the acquisitions of Color Wow and Medik8, and leadership changes effective January 2026. L’Oréal also received high ESG ratings from ISS, MSCI, and Sustainalytics, and three of its innovations were named among TIME’s Best Inventions of 2025. Hieronimus reaffirmed confidence in delivering another year of growth and higher profitability.

headline: Kering and L’Oréal forge an alliance in beauty and wellness
title: Kering and L’Oréal forge an alliance in beauty and wellness
summary: The agreement formalises the sale of Kering’s beauty assets to L’Oréal and establishes a joint strategic committee plus 50-year licences for Gucci, Bottega Veneta, and Balenciaga product development.
full_text: Kering and L’Oréal announced a long-term strategic partnership in luxury beauty and wellness, valued at 4 billion euros and expected to close in the first half of 2026. The agreement includes L’Oréal’s acquisition of the House of Creed and 50-year exclusive licences to develop and distribute fragrance and beauty products for Gucci, Bottega Veneta, and Balenciaga. A strategic committee will oversee collaboration between the two groups. The deal builds on the success of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté and deepens the historic partnership between Kering’s portfolio of luxury brands and L’Oréal’s global beauty expertise. Through Creed, L’Oréal will strengthen its position in the fast-growing niche fragrance market, while the new licences give it long-term exposure to high-end couture labels. Beyond beauty, the two companies will form a 50/50 joint venture to explore business opportunities in wellness and longevity, combining L’Oréal’s innovation capabilities with Kering’s deep understanding of luxury clients. Kering CEO Luca de Meo said the alliance allows Kering to focus on the creative power of its Houses while accelerating growth in beauty and fragrance. L’Oréal CEO Nicolas Hieronimus called it a “decisive step” that reinforces L’Oréal’s leadership in luxury beauty and opens new avenues in wellness. The transaction remains subject to customary conditions and regulatory approvals.
